title: Ex-prison warden used police database to keep tabs on friend’s criminal family
text:
Jacqueline Wilson (left) searched for information on the relatives of her friend Jacqueline Goosey (right) (Picture: Cavendish)

A police receptionist illegally used her force’s confidential database to help her best friend find out about relatives who had been arrested.

Ex-prison warden Jacqueline Wilson, 51, said she used the database ‘like Facebook’ to help Jacqueline Goosey, 52, keep tabs on her criminal family.

The information Wilson shared was described in court as ‘just gossip between friends’.

Wilson agreed to repeatedly make illicit checks on police investigations for former workmate Goosey, whose family were involved in the cases.

While working behind the public inquiry counter at Preston Police station in Lancashire, Wilson checked on Goosey’s husband, son, daughter and two nephews on 12 occasions in relation to a range of offences, including drug driving, assault, criminal damage, robbery and car theft.

Relaying the information back to Goosey, Wilson sent messages including ‘I’ll do some digging’ and ‘it’s a bit difficult to look – putting his name in again’.

The pair, who had been friends for 16 years, were unaware that each search attempt triggered an alert with senior officers at Lancashire Police.

Wilson was handed a suspended sentence for illegally using her force’s police database ‘like Facebook’ to help her best friend out (Picture: Cavendish)

When Goosey was confronted she admitted: ‘I just feel so bad – I’ve asked for this stuff and got her into trouble.

‘She’s my friend and she knows everything about me. To me they were just little questions. I have only asked her to get information for when I have had problems.’

Wilson claimed she thought it was the same as ‘asking at the police station’ and later said her behaviour was similar to ‘somebody checking their Facebook account’.

There was no suggestion she had access to any sensitive intelligence about crime.

Preston Crown Court heard the first illegal search was made by Wilson in April 2017 after Goosey’s nephew was arrested for breach of bail.

The offences then continued on several occasions over a 14 month period.

Defence for Wilson, Rachel Woods, said: ‘Her motivation for this offence was only her aim to simply assist her codefendant and long standing friend who clearly had a complicated family background.’

Goosey asked Wilson to make several checks about a range of offences involving members of her family (Picture: Cavendish)

She added: ‘In her mind she thought what she was doing was confirming the information that her co-defendant had already found. She thought she was simply helping a friend.’

For Goosey, defence lawyer Cecilia Pritchard said: ‘She is a lady with a rather troubled family but she herself has never been in trouble with the police. She was just someone who felt the need to protect her family in the way she thought she would.

‘Sometimes it was just gossip between friends and there was no intention to frustrate any police investigation.

‘She thought she was helping her family out, she was going about it in the wrong way.’

Sentencing Judge Andrew Woolman said no prosecution or police enquiries were affected by the friends’ actions but said the offences have the potential to cause damage to the police system and information to be released into the public domain.

Wilson and Goosey, both of Prestwood, admitted a charge of unauthorised access to computer data.

Wilson was sentenced to six months jail suspended for two years and ordered to pay £85 costs.

Goosey was sentenced to eight months in prison suspended for two years and ordered to pay £1,000 costs.

Both were ordered to complete 150 hours of unpaid work.

How the illegal searches were made Prosecutor Alexander Langhorn told the court how Goosey first asked Wilson to get unauthorised access to the computer data about her nephew’s arrest in April 2017. Later, another nephew was reported missing and Goosey asked Wilson for information. A 40 minute phone call followed, where Wilson relayed what police had found so far. Then when another nephew was arrested for robbery and car theft Goosey messaged Wilson to search for his name. This nephew was rearrested later that day and there was further checks in relation to him. In October 2017, Goosey’s son was arrested for driving while over the prescribed limit for drugs. Wilson used the database to keep her friend ‘up to date with what was happening in custody’. When Goosey’s nephew went on the run in November 2017, Wilson messaged her friend and said: ‘Can’t find anything.’ A short time later, Goosey was reported to have been the victim of assault by her husband. She asked Wilson for an update on her case and asked if she could read the statement she had provided to see if it was OK. Wilson said it was excellent. In December 2017, Wilson searched for information on Goosey’s daughter before telling her friend ‘don’t worry’ and implying the daughter had been found with cocaine. In January 2018, Goosey was herself witness to a murder and she asked Wilson to conduct checks. Wilson reported back that someone had been murdered. When there was another domestic incident between Goosey and her ex-partner, she asked Wilson if the incident had been logged. Wilson said ‘I’ll do some digging’ before later saying: ‘Trying to find out but can’t find anything’.
